action.action-desc: Mr. Nehls (for himself, Mr. Hunt, and Mr. Biggs of Arizona) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To remove aliens who fail to comply with a release order, to enroll all aliens on the nondetained docket of an immigration court in the Alternatives to Detention program with continuous GPS monitoring, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Justice for Jocelyn Act.

section.header: Limitation on participation in alternatives to detention
section.text: No alien may be released as part of any program under the Alternatives to Detention program unless—

paragraph.text: all detention beds available to the Secretary have been filled;
there exists no available option to hold aliens in detention; and
the Secretary exercised and exhausted all reasonable efforts to hold aliens in detention.

section.header: Gps tracking and curfew requirements for certain aliens
section.text: Each alien on the Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s nondetained docket shall be enrolled in the Alternatives to Detention program and—

paragraph.text: shall be continuously subject to GPS monitoring—

subparagraph.text: for the duration of all applicable immigration proceedings, including any appeal; and
in the case of an alien who is ordered removed from the United States, until removal; and

paragraph.text: shall be required to stay in their Alternatives to Detention-compliant home address between the hours of 10 p.m. to 5 a.m.

section.header: Removal of aliens who fail to comply with release order
section.text: Section 240(b)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1229a(b)(5)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.header: Failure to comply with release order
subparagraph.text: In the case that an immigration officer submits an affidavit to an immigration judge stating that an alien failed to comply with a condition of release under section 236(a), such alien shall be ordered removed in absentia.

section.text: If any provision of this Act or the application of such provision to any person or circumstance is held by a Federal court to be unconstitutional, the remainder of this Act and the application of such provisions to any other person or circumstance shall not be affected.
